snippet: Over all, 63 percent of Americans said they supported the new federal requirement that private health insurance plans cover the cost of birth control.
abstract: Close divide in a Senate vote over whether employers can refuse insurance coverage for contraception mirrors a sharp partisan divide among the public; polls show that 63 percent of Americans support the new federal requirement that private health insurance plans cover the cost of birth control; many of those polled also express impatience with the focus on women's reproductive issues in an era of economic distress.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Robbie Brown and Kim Severson in Atlanta, Steven Yaccino in Chicago, Malia Wollan in San Francisco, Ian Lovett in Los Angeles and Dan Frosch in Denver.

lead_paragraph: Over all, 63 percent of Americans said they supported the new federal requirement that private health insurance plans cover the cost of birth control.

headline.seo: Americans Divided on Birth Control Coverage, Poll Finds
headline.main: Poll Finds Wide Support for Birth Control Coverage
headline.print_headline: Poll Finds Divisions Over Requiring Coverage
